Bases: object

Method that retrives the NGon method

get_ngon_a_from_zone_node(n_zone)[source]¶

Retrive the element range and the connectivity ARRAY of the current zone. remember that it is composed as follows: elementConnectivityArray = [num_el_face0, coord[0]…. coord[num_el], num_el_face1, coord[0]…..coord[num_el]]

extraxt the faces and the points for the meshio elaboration. The flag 3D defines if we treat with a 3D or 2D mesh

dualGPy.Graph module¶

class dualGPy.Graph.Graph(mesh)[source]¶

Bases: ABC

Base class for the Graph2D and Graph3D representation. WARNING! 2D and 3D are considered from a geometric point of view:

mesh : Mesh representation from meshio library

dualGPy.Mesh module¶

class dualGPy.Mesh.CellType(value)[source]¶

Bases: IntEnum

Enum for cell types according to how many faces are on the boundary: interior, 0 faces; valley, 1; ridge, 2; corner, 3.

CORNER = 3¶
INTERIOR = 0¶
RIDGE = 2¶
VALLEY = 1¶
class dualGPy.Mesh.Mesh(mesh)[source]¶

Bases: ABC

This is a class interface representing a generic Mesh, 2D or 3D. The Mesh is a wrapper of the meshio object Mesh, containing methods to compute the area and volume (depending of the dimensionality of the problem (2D or 3D). :param mesh: a meshio object

abstract ComputeGeometry(points)[source]¶

compute the volume of the cells with respect to the dimensionality (2D area, 3D volume)

abstract boundary_detection()[source]¶

Run the detection of the connectivity (it verifies the neightborhood for each cell) and fills the dictionaries Dfaces and faces

abstract get_boundary_faces()[source]¶

compute the area of the faces of the cells with respect to the dimensionality (2D length of the segment, 3D area of the face)

abstract setup_mesh()[source]¶

Method that setup the elements to elaborate the graph and hence casts all the cells in a vector starting from a meshio.Mesh object. It fills the cells list of array and the boundary list. The method fills also the vector of the center points of the mesh. Results:

  • class.cells : cells parsed in a list of list

  • class.cell_type : number of point constituting the cell

  • class.centers : centerpoint of each cell (useful for the post processing and visualizations)

class dualGPy.Mesh.Mesh2D(*args)[source]¶

Bases: Mesh

This is a concrete class representing a 2D mesh. The Mesh2D derives from the Mesh and contains concrete methods coming from Mesh.

The constructor of the class takes a variadic list of arguments. It is possible or to give a meshio object (an external mesh given in the datacard or 2 parameters that allows to the constructor to build a meshio object that will represent a 2D mesh of squares (number of element in x will be the same of number of elements in y):

Parameters:

  • n – number of elements in the 2D mesh

  • anisotropic – or true or false it allows to introduce the anisotropicity in one direction

ComputeGeometry()[source]¶

In the case of the 2D class it will be an Area

boundary_detection()[source]¶

automatically determine the boundary condition Right now we generate all the combination of possible faces and we see if they are in the neighborhood. If they are not we print them out.

boundary_detection_Easy()[source]¶

automatically determine the boundary condition, starting from the given graph Right now we generate all the combination of possible faces and we see if they are in the neighborhood. If they are not we print them out.

draw_aggl_lines(string, lines_dict, xlim_min, xlim_max, ylim_min, ylim_max)[source]¶

Draw the mesh and the agglomeration lines that are defined in a dictionary given as an input. This version is the one that plot a window on the mesh. :param string: string of the name of the figure produced :param lines_dict: dictionary where the key is the number of the line and the value is a list of the cells representing this line :param xlim_min: minimum x to plot :param xlim_max: maximum x to plot :param ylim_min: minimum y to plot :param ylim_max: maximum y to plot

draw_aggl_lines_full(string, lines_dict)[source]¶

Draw the mesh and the agglomeration lines that are defined in a dictionary given as an input. This version is the one that plot the whole mesh. :param string: string of the name of the figure produced :param lines_dict: dictionary where the key is the number of the line and the value is a list of the cells representing this line

draw_bnd(string, vector)[source]¶

Draw the mesh and the priority boundaries (for the agglomeration) :param string: string of the name of the figure produced :param vector: vector of the boundaries to draw

draw_graph(string)[source]¶

Draw the mesh and the undirected graph :param string: string of the name of the figure produced

get_boundary_faces()[source]¶

Returns the dual mesh held in a dictionary Graph with dual[“points”] giving the coordinates and dual[“cells”] giving the indicies of all the cells of the dual mesh.

setup_mesh()[source]¶

Method that setup the elements to elaborate the graph and hence casts all the cells in a vector starting from a meshio.Mesh object. It fills the cells list of array and the boundary list. The method fills also the vector of the center points of the mesh. Results:

  • class.cells : cells parsed in a list of list

  • class.cell_type : number of point constituting the cell

  • class.centers : centerpoint of each cell (useful for the post processing and visualizations)

class dualGPy.Mesh.Mesh3D(*args)[source]¶

Bases: Mesh

Implements the 3D mesh: ATTENTION! Right now only tetra supported, but flexible to implement also hexa and pyramids

dualGPy.Utils.get_dual_points(compliant_cells, index)[source]¶
Function that returns the points of the dual mesh nearest to the point in the mesh given by the index.

Parameters: mesh: meshio.Mesh object

Input mesh.

index: int

Index of the point in the input mesh for which to calculate the nearest points of the dual mesh.

Return:

compliant

# Find the cells where the given index appears, REMEMBER the where statement gives you immediately back the indexof the compliant cell # building the compliant cells list
